content.description: This thing is mega! Crank up steep granite on good holds (too good?) until you can cop an uncomfortable rest just beneath the chockstone. Clip the draws on the heroic chockstone and find yourself horizontal, dead-pointing perfect chert knobs. Climb up the front side of the chock for four or five bolts to the chains. Really good granite leads into excellent limestone.
content.location: Climbs up the steep granite, then transfers onto the river-side(front side) of the massive round chockstone.

content.description: Execute a tricky move to reach the ledge and traverse right to reach the arête and a good rest (5.10+). The next part is airy arête climbing and seems to be solid 5.12 to another great rest.  Cruise the final head wall on generally juggy holds (5.10).  This is an amazing pitch with great climbing and airy exposure situated on a hanging arête.
content.location: The right most route, sharing the start of Labor of Hate but immediately traversing the rising ledge to the right to reach the arête.

content.description: Walk into the den, and you're going to want to climb the thirty foot refrigerator arete that rises out of the back. Heavy manufacturing was done on this one by who knows who, but for what it's worth, the vast majority of holds are simply improvements to existing features, so the climbing still has a natural feel. Start on a well-built platform at an incredibly obvious drilled pocket (Stick clip mandatory). Climb a hard intro sequence to some good holds. Find yourself in a V9 or 10 crux before the climbing backs off to around V4 or 5. Cop a rest on a huge jug directly under the arete. The arete is spectacular, all natural 5.12. So so so good. If the drilled pockets were less obvious lower on the route, it'd get that extra star.
content.location: There is one dinky route to the left of this, but for all intent and purpose, Goku is the left-most route in the den.
